# ➤ [Dashboard]() ➤ [Analogue Electronics](Analogue%20Electronics/Analogue%20Electronics.md)

Transistor structure

The npn bipolar transistor contains a thin p-region between two n-regions.
The three regions and their terminal connections are called the emitter, base and collector.


Forward Active Mode Operation

if the transistor is used as an amplifying device, the base-emitter (B-E) junction is reverse biased, in a configuration called the forward-active operating mode, or simply the active region.


Current relationship

npn pnp
$$I_{C} = I_{S}e^{{V_{BE}}\div{V_{T}}}$$ $$I_{C} = I_{S}e^{{V_{EB}}\div{V_{T}}}$$
$$I_{E} = \frac{I_{C}}{\alpha}=\frac{I_{S}}{\alpha}e^{V_{BE}\div V_{T}}$$ $$I_{E} = \frac{I_{C}}{\alpha}=\frac{I_{S}}{\alpha}e^{V_{EB}\div V_{T}}$$
$$I_{B} = \frac{I_{C}}{\beta}=\frac{I_{S}}{\beta}e^{V_{BE}\div V_{T}}$$ $$I_{E} = \frac{I_{C}}{\beta}=\frac{I_{S}}{\beta}e^{V_{EB}\div V_{T}}$$
For both transistor
$$I_{E} = I_{C} + I_{B}$$ $$I_{C}=\beta I_{B}$$
$$I_{E} = (1 + \beta)I_{B}$$ $$I_{C}=\alpha I_{E}=\left(\frac{\beta}{1 + \beta}\right)I_{E}$$
$$\alpha = \frac{\beta}{1 + \beta}$$ $$\beta = \frac{\alpha}{1 - \alpha}$$

# ➤ [Dashboard]() ➤ [Analogue Electronics](Analogue%20Electronics/Analogue%20Electronics.md)

FET vs BJT

FET BJT


• 3 terminal device • 3 terminal device emitter to collector $e^{-}$ current controlled by the current injected into the base.
• Channel $e^{-}$ current from source to drain controlled by the electric field.
• Extremely high input impedance for base.

Types of FETs

In addition to carrier type (N or P channel), there are differences in how to control element is constructed (Junction $\times$ Insulated) and those devices must be used differently.

Depletion mode junction FETs (JFET) npn
pnp
Metal oxide semi-conductor FET (MOSTFET) npn
pnp
• depletion/enhancement mode
• enhancement mode

MOSFET Operation

• The thershold voltage of the n-channel MOSFET, denoted as $V_{TN}$, is defined as the applied gate voltage needed to create an inversion of charge in which the density is equal to the concentration of majority carriers in the semiconductor subtrate.
• In simple terms, we can think of a threshold voltage as the gate voltage required to turn on the transistor.


I-V current-voltage relationship

• For N-MOSFET
• The non saturation mode
$\begin{gathered}I_{D} = K_{n}[2(V_{gs} - V_{TN})v_{ds} - v_{ds}^{2}]\end{gathered}$
• The saturation mode
$\begin{aligned}I_{D} = K_{n}(V_{gs} - V_{TN})^{2}\end{aligned}$
$\begin{aligned}V_{DS}(sat) = V_{gs} - V_{TN}\end{aligned}$
• The conduction mode
$\begin{aligned}K_{n} = \frac{W\mu_{n}C_{ox}}{2L}\end{aligned}$
$\begin{aligned}K_{n}=\frac{k'_{n}}{2}\cdot\frac{W}{L}\end{aligned}$

$C_{ox}: $ the oxide capacitance per unit area.
$\mu_{n}: $ the mobility of the electrons in the inversion layer.
$\frac{W}{L}:$ the width-to-length ratio.
$k'_{n} = \mu_{n}C_{ox}: $ the process conduction parameter.

Example

For the transistor in the circuit below, the parameters are $V_{TN} = 0.4V$, $k'_{n}=120\mu A\cdot V^{-2}$, and $\frac{W}{L} = 25$.


Determine $V_{GS}$, $I_{D}$ and $V_{DS}$. Sketch the load line and plot the Q- point.

TODO: solve

Small signal analysis

$\begin{aligned}g_{m} = 2\sqrt{K_{n}I_{DQ}}\end{aligned}$
$g_{m}$ is the solpe of the curve and is a constant called the transconductance.
$\begin{aligned}r_{o}=[\lambda K_{n}(V_{GSQ} - V_{TN})^{2}]^{-1}\approx[\lambda I_{DQ}]^{-1}\end{aligned}$
$\lambda$ is the channel-length modulation parameter and is a positive quantity.


Basic transistor amplifier configurations

$\begin{aligned}V_{o} = -g_{m}V_{gs}(r_{o}||R_{D})\end{aligned}$
The input gate-to source voltage is:
$\begin{aligned}V_{gs} = \left(\frac{R_{i}}{R_{i} + R_{si}}\right)V_{i}\end{aligned}$
So the small-signal voltage gain is:
$\begin{aligned}A_{v} = \frac{V_{o}}{V_{i}}=-g_{m}(r_{o}||R_{D})\left(\frac{R_{i}}{R_{i}+R_{si}}\right)\end{aligned}$


Example

Determine the small signal voltage gain, input and output resistance of a common-source amplifier.
$V_{DD} = 3.3V$
$R_{D} = 10k\Omega$
$R_{1} = 140k\Omega$
$R_{2} = 60k\Omega$
$R_{si} = 4k\Omega$
. The transistor parameters are:
$V_{TN} = 0.4V$
$K_{n} = 0.5mA\cdot V^{-2}$
$\lambda = 0.02V^{-1}$

Solution:
$\begin{aligned}V_{GSQ}=\left(\frac{R_{2}}{R_{1} + R_{2}}\right)V_{DD} = \left(\frac{60}{140 + 60}\right)(3.3) = 0.99V\end{aligned}$
The quiescent drain current is:
$\begin{aligned}V_{DSQ} = V_{DD} - I_{DQ}R_{D} = 3.3 - (0.174)(10) = 1.56V\end{aligned}$
Since $V_{DSQ} > V_{GSQ} - V_{TN}$, the transistor is biased in the saturation region.
Small-signal voltage gain:
$\begin{aligned}g_{m} = 2\sqrt{K_{n}I_{DQ}} = 2\sqrt{(0.5)(0.174)} = 0.590mA\cdot V^{-1}\end{aligned}$
and the small-signal output resistance is:
$\begin{aligned}r_{o} = \frac{1}{\lambda I_{DQ}}=\frac{1}{(0.02)(0.174)}=287\Omega\end{aligned}$
The output resistance to the amplifier is:
$\begin{aligned}R_{i} = R_{1}||R_{2}=140||60 = 42k\Omega\end{aligned}$
The small-voltage gain is:
$\begin{aligned}A_{v} = -g_{m}(r_{o}||R_{D})\left(\frac{R_{i}}{R_{i}+R_{si}}\right)=-(0.59)(287||10)\left(\frac{42}{42+4}\right)=-5.21\end{aligned}$
Input and Output resistance
As already calculated, the amplifier input resistance is:
$\begin{aligned}R_{i} = R1||R2 = 140||60 = 42k\Omega\end{aligned}$
and the amplifier output resistance is:
$\begin{aligned}R_{o} = R_{D}||r_{o} = 10||287 = 9.66k\Omega\end{aligned}$

# ➤ [Dashboard]() ➤ [Analogue Electronics](Analogue%20Electronics/Analogue%20Electronics.md)

Op-amp Introduction

• Op-amps (amplifier / buffers in general) are drawn as a triangle in a circuit schematic
• There are two inputs: inverting and non-inverting
• And one ouput
• Also power connection (note no explicit ground)
Input Output
$V_{1} > V_{2}$ $V^{+}$
$V_{2} > V_{1}$ $V^{-}$

Application WIP

Temperature (°C) Voltage (V)
0° 0V
25° 2.5V
50° 5V

If we want to control a system when the temperature is greater than 25°C, we can design this circuit.


$$A_{v} = 1 + \frac{R_{f}}{R_{1}}$$ $$$$


Buffer

$$A_{v} = \frac{V_{o}}{V_{i}}=1$$

Works as a buffer.


Non-inverting amplifiers

$$A_{v} = \frac{v_{o}}{v_{i}} = 1 + \frac{R_{2}}{R_{1}}$$ The purpose is Amplification only.


Inverting amplifier

$$A_{v} = \frac{v_{o}}{v_{I}} = -\frac{R_{2}}{R_{1}}$$ The purpose is Amplification, attenuation and inverting


Summing Amplifier

Amplifying the superposition method
$$v_{o}(v_{I1}) = I_{1}R_{F} = \frac{-R_{F}}{R_{1}}v_{I1}$$ $$v_{o}(v_{I2}) = I_{2}R_{F} = \frac{-R_{F}}{R_{2}}v_{I2}$$ $$v_{o}(v_{I3}) = I_{3}R_{F} = \frac{-R_{F}}{R_{3}}v_{I3}$$ $$v_{o} = v_{o}(v_{I1}) + v_{o}(v_{I2}) + v_{o}(v_{I3})$$ $$v_{o} = -\left(\frac{R_{F}}{R_{1}}v_{I1} + \frac{R_{F}}{R_{2}}v_{I2} + \frac{R_{F}}{R_{3}}v_{I3}\right)$$ The purpose is Summing, Amplification, Attenuation and Inverting


Difference Amplifier WIP

$$v_{o1} = \frac{R_{2}}{R_{1}}v_{I1}$$ $$v_{o2} = \left(\frac{1 + R_{2}}{R_{1}}\right)\left(\frac{R_{4}}{R_{3} + R_{4}}\right)v_{I2}$$ $$v_{2b}=\frac{R_{4}}{R_{3}+R_{4}}v_{I2}$$ $$v_{o} = v_{o1} + v_{o2}$$ $$v_{o} = \frac{R_{2}}{R_{1}}(v_{I2} - V_{I1})$$


Current to Voltage converter WIP

$$i_{2} = i_{1} = i_{s}$$ $$v_{o} = -i_{2}R_{F} = -i_{s}R_{F}$$


Voltage to Current converter WIP

$$i_{L} = \frac{\frac{R_{F}Z_{L}}{R_{1}R_{3}} - 1 - Z_{L}}{R_{3}}$$


Integrator and Differentiator

Differentiator Integrator
$$v_{o} = -R_{2}C_{1} \frac{dv_{I}(t)}{dt}$$ $$v_{o} = \frac{-1}{R_{1}C_{2}}\int_{0}^{t}v_{I}(t')dt'$$

Design example

A sensor output a voltage from -2.4 to -1.1V. For an interface to an A/D, this needs to be 0 to 2.5V. Develop the required signal conditioning.
$$v_{o}=1.92*(V_i)+4.61$$ Using a summing amplifier and an inverting amplifier

$$v_{o} = -R_{F}\left(\frac{V_{1}}{R_{1}}+\frac{V_{2}}{R_{2}}\right)(-1)$$ $$v_{o} = 1.92\left(V_{in} + \frac{4.6}{1.92}\right)$$ $\begin{gathered}R_{F} = 1.92k\Omega\end{gathered}$
$\begin{gathered}R_{1} = 1k\Omega\end{gathered}$
$\begin{gathered} \frac{V_{2}}{R_{2}} = \frac{1.92}{4.6} \Rightarrow V_{2} = 1.92V, R_{2} = 4.6k\Omega\end{gathered}$

Using a subractor amplifier

$$v_{o} = \frac{R_{2}}{R_{1}}(V_{2} - V_{1})$$ $\begin{gathered} \frac{R_{2}}{R_{1}} = 1.92\Omega \Rightarrow R_{1} = 1k\Omega, R_{2} = 1.92k\Omega\end{gathered}$
$\begin{gathered}v_{2} = V_{in}\end{gathered}$
$\begin{gathered}v_{1} = -2.4V\end{gathered}$

# ➤ [Dashboard]() ➤ [Analogue Electronics](Analogue%20Electronics/Analogue%20Electronics.md)

Diode

A diode is an electrical component that allows the flow of current in only one direction.
In circuit diagrams, a diode is represented by a triangle with a line across one vertex.
Silicon (Si) and germanium (Ge) are elemental semiconductors used in the diode manufacturing.


PN Junction

The n-regions contains many more free electrons than the p-region; similarly, the p-region contains many more holes than the n-region.
If a positive voltage is applied to the p-region, the potential barrier decreases.
Majority carrier electrons from the n-region diffuse into the p-region, and majority carrier holes from the p-region diffuse into the n-region.
The process continues as long as the voltage is applied, thus creating a current in the pn junction.


Ideal diode

The idea diode:
The I-V characteristics of the ideal diode.

Equivalent circuit under reverse bias (an open circuit).

Equivalent circuit in the conducting state (a short circuit).


PN Junction diode

$$I_{D} = I_{S}\left[e^{\left(\frac{v_{D}}{nV_{T}}\right)}-1\right]$$ the parameter $I_{S}$ is the reverse-bias saturation current. For silicon pn junctions, typical values are in the range $10^{-18}$ to $10^{-12}\text{A}$.
The parameter $V_{T}$ is the thermal voltage and is approximately $V_{T} = 0.026\text{V}$ at room temperature.
The parameter $n$ is usually called the emission coefficient or ideality factor, and its value is in the range $1 \leq n \leq 2$

Zener Diode

This makes a zener diode useful in a voltage regulator, or a constant-voltage reference circuit.


I-V characteristics during breakdown effects


Voltage regulator circuit

$$R_{i}=\frac{V_{PS}-V_{Z}}{I_{i}}=\frac{V_{PS}-V_{Z}}{I_{Z} + I_{L}}$$ Which assumes that the Zener resistance is zero for the ideal diode. Solving this equation for the diode current $I_{Z}$, we get:
$$I_{Z}=\frac{V_{PS}-V_{Z}}{R_{i}}-I_{L}$$ Where $I_{L} = \frac{V_{Z}}{R_{L}}$, and the variables are the input voltage source $V_{PS}$ and the load current $I_{L}$.

# ➤ [Dashboard]() ➤ [Differential Equation & Laplace](Differential%20Equation%20&%20Laplace/Differential%20Equation%20&%20Laplace.md)

Equation

An equation is an expression of a relationship between quantities, also called variables or unknowns.
A solution of an equation is a value for the variable(s) that makes the expression true after substitution.


Differential equation

A differential equation is an expression of a relationship between a quantity and the rate of change of that same quantity, or a relationship between a quantity and its own derivative.
A differential equation has two type of variable:
- The independant variable.
- The dependant variable.


Rl Circuit

Consider the following RL circuit:

The voltage across the resistor: $\htmlClass{salmon}{u_{R}} = i\times R$
The voltage across the inductor: $\htmlClass{blue}{u_{L}} = L\times \frac{di}{dt}$
Kirchhoff's voltage law: $\htmlClass{blue}{u_{L}} + \htmlClass{salmon}{u_{R}} = E(t)$
$$L\times \frac{di}{dt} + i\times R = E(t)$$ A differential equation!
t is the independent variable, i is the dependent variable.


example

Newton's law of cooling says:
- the speed of cooling of an object is proportional to the difference in temperature of the object and its surrounding.
- Take $T = T(t)$, the temperature of the object at time $t$
- The rate of change in temperature equals $\frac{dT}{dt}$
- Take $T_{0}$ the temperature of the surrounding.
- $\frac{dT}{dt} = k(T - T_{0})$ where k is the constant of proportion.
- The independent variable is $t$, the dependent variable is $T$.


eaxmple

A cake is baked in an oven at $120\degree C$.
At time $t = 0$ it is moved from the oven into the open air, $T_{0} = 20\degree C$.
After 5 minutes, the temperature of the cake is $80\degree C$.
Give the temperature of the cake as a function of time in minutes.
Corresponding differential equation:
$$\frac{dT}{dt} = k(T-T_{0})$$ $T_{0} = 20$, $T(0) = 120$, $T(5) = 80$


Dependent and independent variables

A differential equation is about quantity as a function of another quantity, eg. temperature as a function of time, or voltage as a function of time, or the speed of flow as a function of location.
Time and location are usualy the independent variables.
The functions are the dependent variables.
In a differential equation they are easy to recognize:
$\frac{dy}{dx}$ indicates that $x$ is independent, and $y$ is dependent.


The order of a differential equation

$\frac{df}{dx}$ is the first derivative of $f$.
if we differentiate this derivative again, then we get the second derivative of $f$: $\frac{d^{2}f}{dx^{2}}$
This is called: a derivative of second order.
In a differential equation, it is possible to have derivatives of various order.
The highest order derivative in a differential equation determines the order of the differential equation.


Example

$$\frac{dQ}{dt} + 4Q = sin(t)$$ Which is the indepent variable? $\htmlClass{springgreen bold}{t}$
Which is the dependent variable? $\htmlClass{springgreen bold}{Q}$
What is the order? 1st $$\frac{d^{2}y}{dq^{2}} + q^{3} \frac{dy}{dq}+5y^{4}= 0$$ Which is the indepent variable? $\htmlClass{springgreen bold}{q}$
Which is the dependent variable? $\htmlClass{springgreen bold}{y}$
What is the order? 2st


Linear differential equations

A differential equation is called linear if it is possible to write it as:
$$a_{n} \frac{d^{n}x}{dt^{n}}+a_{n-1} \frac{d^{n-1}}{dt^{n-1}}+\cdots+a_{1} \frac{dx}{dt} + a_{0}x = r(t)$$ where $a_{0}$, $a_{1}$, $\cdots$, $a_{n}$ can be function of $t$.
Pay attention tot he role of the dependent variable.
In each term, it may only occur as itself or it's derivative.


Example

Linear Non-linear
$$\frac{d^{2}y}{dq^{2}} + q^{3}\frac{dy}{dq}+5y = 10q$$ $$\frac{d^{2}y}{dq^{2}} + q^{3}\frac{dy}{dq}+5y^{4} = 10q$$
$$\frac{dy}{dx}+5x^{4} = 0$$ $$\frac{dy}{dx} + 5y^{4}=0$$
$$x \frac{dy}{dx} + 5xy = \sqrt{x^{2} + 1}$$ $$y \frac{dy}{dx} + x = 0$$
$$\frac{d^{2}x}{dt^{2}}+5 \frac{dx}{dt} = 6x + 10t$$ $$\left(\frac{dx}{dt}\right)^{2} + 5 \frac{dx}{dt} = 6x + 10t$$
$$\frac{dy}{dx} + 5y = \sin(x)$$ $$\frac{dy}{dx} + 5x = \sin(y)$$

Solution of a differential equation

The solution of an ordinary equation is a number (or various numbers).
The solution of a differential equation is a function: the dependent variable is a function of the independent variable.
You can check a candidate solution by substitution into the differential equation.
The formula that is formed by this substitution must be true for every value of the independent variable.


Example

$$\frac{dx}{dt} = x$$ Which function can be substituted for $x$ to make the formula true?
Which function is equal to it's own derivative?
$$x = e^{t}$$ Substitute:
$$\frac{dx}{dt}(e^{t})=e^{t}$$ Any other function?
$$x=C\cdot e^t$$ Substitute:
$$\frac{dx}{dt}(C\cdot e^{t})=C\cdot e^{t}$$


Example

$$\frac{dx}{dt}=-2x+2t$$ Is the function $x = t - \frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{2}e^{-2t}$ a solution?
Substitute:
$$\frac{dx}{dt}\left(t - \frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{2}e^{-2t}\right) = -2\left(t - \frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{2}e^{-2t}\right)+ 2t$$ $$1-e^{-2t}\neq-2t + 1 - e^{-2t} + 2t$$ No


Homogeneous differential equation

We have a differential equation with $t$ as independent variable and $x$ as dependent variable.
The differential equation is called homogeneous if the function $x = 0$ (so for every $t$ the function $x(t)$) is a solution of the differential equation.


Example

$$\frac{d^{2}x}{dt^{2}}+5 \frac{dx}{dt} = 6x$$ Substitute: $x = 0$, then $\frac{dx}{dt} = 0$ and $\frac{d^{2}x}{dt^{2}} = 0$, so $0 + 5\cdot0 = 6\cdot0$.
And that is correct, so this differential equation is homogeneous.

/Differential-Equation-Laplace/Lesson-10.title: Lesson 10
/Differential-Equation-Laplace/Lesson-10.content:
# ➤ [Dashboard]() ➤ [Differential Equation & Laplace](Differential%20Equation%20&%20Laplace/Differential%20Equation%20&%20Laplace.md)

Linearity property

Let $\mathcal{L}(f(t)) = F(s)$ and $\mathcal{L}(g(t)) = G(s)$
Let $\alpha$ and $\beta$ be constants.
Then: $\mathcal{L}(\alpha f(t) + \beta g(t)) = \alpha F(s) + \beta G(s)$


Shift in s-domain

If $\mathcal{L}(f(t)) = F(s)$ then $\mathcal{L}(e^{at} \cdot f(t)) = F(s - a)$
In words: multiply by an exponential in time means shift in s-domain.
Proof:
$$\begin{align*}\mathcal{L}(e_{at}\cdot f(t)) &= \int^{\infty}_{0}e^{at}\cdot f(t)\cdot e^{-st}dt\newline&=\int^{\infty}_{0} f(t) \cdot e^{-(s - a)t}dt \newline&= F(s - a)\end{align*}$$


Differentiate in s-domain

If $\mathcal{L}(f(t)) = F(s)$ then $\mathcal{L}(t\cdot f(t)) = -\frac{dF(s)}{ds}$
In words: multiply by t in time means differentiate in s-domain, times - 1.
Proof:
$$F(s) = \int_{0}^{\infty} f(t)\cdot e^{-st} dt$$ $$\begin{align*}\Leftrightarrow \frac{dF(s)}{ds} &= \frac{d}{ds}\int_{0}^{\infty} f(t) \cdot e^{-st}dt\newline&=\int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{d}{ds}f(t)\cdot e^{-st} dt\newline&=\int_{0}^{\infty} f(t)\cdot \frac{d}{ds}e^{-st}dt\newline&=\int_{0}^{\infty} f(t)\cdot (-t) \cdot e^{-st}dt\newline&=-\int_{0}^{\infty} t\cdot f(t)\cdot e^{-st}dt = -\mathcal{L}(t\cdot f(t))\end{align*}$$


Table of transforms

$$f(t)$$ $$F(s) = \mathcal{L}(f(t))$$
$$c$$ $$\frac{c}{s}$$
$$t$$ $$\frac{1}{s^{2}}$$
$$t^{n}$$ $$\frac{n!}{s^{n+1}}$$
$$e^{at}$$ $$\frac{1}{s - a}$$
$$sin(at)$$ $$\frac{a}{s^{2} + a^{2}}$$
$$cos(at)$$ $$\frac{s}{s^{2} + a^{2}}$$

Lesson 9 ⮜ ... ⮞ Lesson 11

/Differential-Equation-Laplace/Lesson-11.title: Lesson 11
/Differential-Equation-Laplace/Lesson-11.content:
# ➤ [Dashboard]() ➤ [Differential Equation & Laplace](Differential%20Equation%20&%20Laplace/Differential%20Equation%20&%20Laplace.md)

Inverse Laplace Transform

If $\mathcal{L}(f(t)) = F(s)$ then $\mathcal{L}^{-1}(F(s)) = f(t)$


Shift in s

$$\mathcal{L}^{-1} = \left(\frac{1}{(s + 2)^{5}}\right)$$ First: $\mathcal{L}^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{s^{5}}\right)= \frac{1}{24}t^{4}$
Then: $\mathcal{L}^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{(s + \htmlClass{blue}{2})^{5}}\right) = \frac{1}{24}t^{4} \cdot \htmlClass{blue}{e^{-2t}}$

$$\mathcal{L}^{-1} = \left(\frac{s + 1}{(s - 3)^{2} + 4}\right)$$ $\begin{aligned}\mathcal{L}^{-1}\left(\frac{s + 1}{(s - 3)^{2} + 4}\right) = \mathcal{L}^{-1}\left(\frac{s - 3}{(s - 3)^{2} + 4}\ + \frac{4}{(s - 3)^{2} + 4}\right)\end{aligned}$
$\begin{aligned}\mathcal{L}^{-1}\left(\frac{s \htmlClass{blue}{-3}}{(s \htmlClass{blue}{-3})^{2} + 4}\right) = cos(2t)\cdot\htmlClass{blue}{e^{3t}}\end{aligned}$
$\begin{aligned}\mathcal{L}^{-1}\left(\frac{4}{(s \htmlClass{blue}{-3})^{2} + 4}\right) = \frac{4}{2}sin(2t)\cdot\htmlClass{blue}{e^{3t}}\end{aligned}$
$\begin{aligned}\text{So }\mathcal{L}^{-1}\left(\frac{s + 1}{(s + 3)^{2} + 4}\right) = cos(2t)\cdot e^{3t} + 2 sin(2t)\cdot e^{3t}\end{aligned}$


Partial fraction

$$\mathcal{L}^{-1}\left(\frac{2s + 1}{s^{2} - 3s}\right)$$ First split the fraction:
$$\frac{2s + 1}{s^{2} - 3s}=\frac{2s + 1}{s(s - 3)} = \frac{A}{s} + \frac{B}{s-3}$$ Partial fraction: $A = \frac{-1}{3}$ and $B = \frac{7}{3}$
$$\mathcal{L}^{-1}\left(\frac{2s + 1}{s^{2} - 3s}\right) = \frac{-1}{3}\mathcal{L}^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{s}\right)+ \frac{7}{3}\mathcal{L}^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{s-3}\right)=-\frac{1}{3} + \frac{7}{3}e^{3t}$$

Lesson 10 ⮜ ... ⮞ Lesson 12

/Differential-Equation-Laplace/Lesson-12.title: Lesson 12
/Differential-Equation-Laplace/Lesson-12.content:
# ➤ [Dashboard]() ➤ [Differential Equation & Laplace](Differential%20Equation%20&%20Laplace/Differential%20Equation%20&%20Laplace.md)

Properties until now

Let $\mathcal{L}(f(t)) = F(s)$ and $\mathcal{L}(g(t)) = G(s)$ and $\alpha$ and $\beta$ are constants.
1. Linearity: $$\mathcal{L}(\alpha f(t) + \beta g(t)) = \alpha F(s) + \beta G(s)$$ 2. Shift in s-domain: $$\mathcal{L}(e^{at}\cdot f(t)) = F(s - a)$$ 3. Differentiate in s-domain: $$\mathcal{L}(t\cdot f(t)) = -dF\frac{s}{ds}$$


Differentiate in t-domain

If $\mathcal{L}(f(t)) = F(s)$ then $\mathcal{L}(f'(t)) = s\cdot F(s) - f(0)$
In words: differentiate in time means: multiply by s in s-domain, minus f(0)


Remarks

This property will be used mainly when we want to transform differential equations.
We can generalize the property for higher order derivatives:
$$\mathcal{L}(f'(t)) = s\cdot F(s) - f(0)$$ $$\begin{align*}\mathcal{L}(f''(t)) &= s\cdot \htmlClass{fushia}{\mathcal{L}(f'(t))} - f'(0)\newline &= s\cdot \htmlClass{fushia}{(s\cdot F(s) - f(0))} - f'(0)\newline &= s^{2} \cdot F(s) - s \cdot f(0) - f'(0)\end{align*}$$


Application

$$\frac{dx}{dt} = 3x + 1    \htmlClass{babyblue}{x(0) = 2}$$ First: let $\mathcal{L}(x) = X$
Then (differentiation property):
$$\mathcal{L}\left(\frac{dx}{dt}\right) = s\cdot X - \htmlClass{babyblue}{x(0)} = s\cdot X - \htmlClass{babyblue}{2}$$ Linearity: $\mathcal{L}(3x + 1) = 3\cdot X + \frac{1}{s}$
$\begin{aligned}\text{So: } s \cdot X - 2 = 3 \cdot X + \frac{1}{s}\end{aligned}$
This is an ordinary equation.
$$\begin{align*} (s - 3)\cdot X = 2 + \frac{1}{s}\newline X = \frac{2 + \frac{1}{s}}{s - 3} = \frac{2s + 1}{s(s - 3)} = \frac{A}{s} + \frac{B}{s-3} \end{align*}$$ Partial fraction: $A = -\frac{1}{3}$ and $B = \frac{7}{3}$
$\begin{aligned}\text{Inverse transform:}x = - \frac{1}{3}\mathcal{L}^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{s}\right) + \frac{7}{3}\mathcal{L}^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{s-3}\right) = \frac{-1}{3} + \frac{7}{3}e^{3t}\end{aligned}$

Lesson 11 ⮜ ... ⮞ Lesson 13

/Differential-Equation-Laplace/Lesson-2.title: Lesson 2
/Differential-Equation-Laplace/Lesson-2.content:
# ➤ [Dashboard]() ➤ [Differential Equation & Laplace](Differential%20Equation%20&%20Laplace/Differential%20Equation%20&%20Laplace.md)

Serparating variables

A differential equation has two variables.
For some differential equations it is possible to separate the variables: on the left-hand-side there is just the dependent and on the right-hand-side just the independent variable.
$$\begin{gather*} \frac{dx}{dt} = x\cdot t\newline dx = x\cdot t\cdot dt\newline \frac{1}{x}dx = t\cdot dt \end{gather*}$$ Take the integral of both sides:
$\int{\frac{1}{x}}\ dx = \int{t}\ dt$ Calculate the integrals
$\ln(x) + C_{1} = \frac{1}{2}t^{2} + C_{2}$ Combine de constants
$\ln(x) = \frac{1}{2}t^{2} + C_{3}$ $C_{3} = C_{2} - C_{1}$
$x = e^{\frac{1}{2}t^{2}+C_{3}}$ Simplify
$x=C\cdot e^{\frac{1}{2}t^{2}}$ $C = e^{C_{3}}$


Remarks

While calculating the integrals you can directly drop one of the integration constants.
Try to write the answer in an explicit form (this is not always possible).
Implicit: $\ln(x) = \frac{1}{2}t^{2} + C_{3}$
Explicit: $x = C\cdot e^{\frac{1}{2}t^{2}}$


Example

$$(t + 1) \frac{dx}{dt} = 3x^{2}$$ $$(t + 1)dx = 3x^{2}dt$$ $$\frac{1}{x^{2}}dx=\frac{3}{t+1}dt$$ $$\int{\frac{1}{x^{2}}}dx=\int{\frac{3}{t+1}}dt$$ $$-\frac{1}{x}=3\ln(t + 1) + C$$ $$x = - \frac{1}{3\ln(x+1) + C}$$


Example

$$(t^{2} + 4) \frac{dx}{dt} = x - 5$$ $$(t^{2} + 4)dx = (x - 5)dt$$ $$\frac{1}{x-5}dx=\frac{1}{t^{2}+4}dt$$ $$\int{\frac{1}{x-5}}dx=\int{\frac{1}{t^{2}+4}}dt$$ $$\ln(x-5)=\frac{1}{2}arctan\left(\frac{t}{2}\right)+C_{1}$$ $$x-5=e^{\frac{1}{2}\arctan\left(\frac{t}{2}\right)+C_{1}}$$ $$x=5+C\cdot e^{\frac{1}{2}\arctan\left(\frac{t}{2}\right)}$$


#
Lesson 1 ⮜ ... ⮞ Lesson 3

/Differential-Equation-Laplace/Lesson-3.title: Lesson 3
/Differential-Equation-Laplace/Lesson-3.content:
# ➤ [Dashboard]() ➤ [Differential Equation & Laplace](Differential%20Equation%20&%20Laplace/Differential%20Equation%20&%20Laplace.md)

Direction field

A differential equation can be visualised in a sol called direction field.
This direction field is a drawing of small line segments in many points.
The line segment in point $P$ indicates in which direction the solution of the equation goes, if the solution should pass $P$.
This direction can be calculated by substituting the coordinates of $P$ into the differential equation.


Example

$$\frac{dy}{dx}=- \frac{x}{y}$$ Take the point $P_{1}(2, 1)$: $\frac{dy}{dx}=- \frac{2}{1} = -2$
Draw through $P_{1}$ a small line segment in this direction.
Take the point $P_{2}(5, 3)$:
$$\frac{dy}{dx}=-\frac{5}{3}$$ Take the point $P_{3}(0, 5)$
$$\frac{dy}{dx} = - \frac{0}{5} = 0$$ Repeat this in many points.


Boundary value

The direction field show the kind of solutions for this equation: circles!
There are infinitely many solutions of the DE.
Which circle is the solution, depends on the boundary value.
If you know one point of a specific solution then the rest is fixed.


Example

$$\frac{dy}{dx}=\frac{-x}{y}, y(0) = 4$$ We will solve the differential equation by separating the variables:
$$\begin{align*}y\space dy &= -x\space dx\newline\int{y\space dy}&=\int{-x\space dx}\newline \frac{1}{2}y^{2}&=\frac{-1}{2}x^{2}+C_{1}\newline x^{2}+y^{2}&=C\end{align*}$$ These are indeed circles. Substitute the boundary value: if $x = 0$ then $y = 4$, so $C = 16$. The radius is $4$


Example

$$\frac{dx}{dt}=\frac{e^{3t}}{x}, x(0) = 2$$ $$x^{2} = \frac{2}{3}e^{3t}+2C$$ $x(0) = 2$ means: if t=0 then x=2, Substitute:
$$2^{2}=\frac{2}{3}e^{0}+2C$$ $$4=\frac{2}{3}+2C \rightarrow 2C = 4 - \frac{2}{3} = \frac{10}{3}$$ The solution is $x=\sqrt{\frac{2}{3}e^{3t} + \frac{10}{3}}$


Example

A cake is baked in an oven at $120\degree C$
At time $t = 0$ it is moved from the oven into the open air, $T_{0} = 20\degree C$.
After 5 minutes, the temperature of the cake is $80\degree C$.
Give the temperature of the cake as a function of time in minutes.
Corresponding differential equation:
$$\frac{dT}{dt}=k(T-T_{0}), T_{0}=20, T(0)=120, T(5)=80$$ The solution:
$$\begin{align*} \frac{dT}{dt}&=k(T-T_{0})\newline \frac{1}{T-T_{0}}dT &= k\space dt\newline\int{\frac{1}{T-T_{0}}}dT&=\int{k\space dt}\newline ln(T-T_{0})&=kt+C_{1}\newline T - T_{0} &= C\space e_{kt}\newline T &= T_{0}+C\space e^{kt} \end{align*}$$ $$T=T_{0} + C\space e^{kt}, T(0) = 120, T(5) = 80, T_{0} = 20$$ $$120=20 + C\rightarrow C = 100$$ $$80=20+100\cdot e_{5k}\newline e^{5k}=\frac{60}{100}=\frac{3}{5}\newline 5k=ln(\frac{3}{5})\newline k = \frac{1}{5}ln(\frac{3}{5})\approx -0.102$$ $$T = 20 + 100 e^-0.102t$$

Lesson 2 ⮜ ... ⮞ Lesson 4

/Differential-Equation-Laplace/Lesson-4.title: Lesson 4
/Differential-Equation-Laplace/Lesson-4.content:
# ➤ [Dashboard]() ➤ [Differential Equation & Laplace](Differential%20Equation%20&%20Laplace/Differential%20Equation%20&%20Laplace.md)

Linear first-order homogenous differential equations

General form: $\frac{dx}{dt} + p(t)\cdot x = 0$
The solution can be found by separating variables.
$$\begin{align*}\frac{dx}{dt}&=-p(t)\cdot x\newline \frac{1}{x}\space dx &= -p(t)\space dt\newline \int{\frac{1}{x}}\space dx &= \int{-p(t)}\space dt\newline ln(x) &= -P(t) + C_{1}\newline x&=C\cdot e^{-P(t)}\end{align*}$$


Shortcut

$$\frac{dx}{dt}+p(t)\cdot x = 0$$
Solution: $x = C\cdot e^{-P(t)}$
Here $P(t)$ is a primitive of $p(t)$.

Example: $\frac{dx}{dt} + 2tx = 0$
Solution: $x = C\cdot e^{-t^{2}}$
Example: $\frac{dx}{dt} + cos(t)\cdot x = 0$
Solution: $x = C\cdot e^{-\sin(t)}$


Example

$$t\cdot \frac{dx}{dt}+3x=0$$ First rewrite: $$\frac{dx}{dt}+ \frac{3}{t}\cdot x = 0$$ A primitive function of $\frac{3}{t}$ is $3 ln(t)$
Solution: $x = C\cdot e^{-3 ln(t)}$
Simplify: $x = C\cdot e^{ln(t^{-3})} = \frac{C}{t^{3}}$


#
Lesson 3 ⮜ ... ⮞ Lesson 5

/Differential-Equation-Laplace/Lesson-5.title: Lesson 5
/Differential-Equation-Laplace/Lesson-5.content:
# ➤ [Dashboard]() ➤ [Differential Equation & Laplace](Differential%20Equation%20&%20Laplace/Differential%20Equation%20&%20Laplace.md)

Non homogenous differential equation

$$\frac{dx}{dt} + p(t)\cdot x = r(t)$$ If $r(t) \neq 0$ then this linear differential equation is not homogenous.
The solution (in general) can not be found using the method of separating variables.
We only consider situations where $p(t)$ is a constant. So:
$$\frac{dx}{dt} + p\cdot x = r(t)$$ Method: first calculate the homogenous part of the solution.
Homogeneous part of the solution:
$$x_{h} = C\cdot e^{-p\cdot t}$$ Note: this is not a solution of the differential equation!
Because substitution for $x = 0$ results into 0 for the lefhandside, but the righthandside still will be $r(t)$.
We are looking for an $x_{a}$ that is a solution of the differential equation.
The general solution then becomes : $x = x_{a} + x_{h}$


Example

$$\frac{dx}{dt} + 3x = 2t + 1$$ First the homogeneous part:
$$x_{h}= C\cdot e^{-3t}$$ How to find $x_a$?
Try something in the form of the righthandside, in this case $2t + 1$ (straight line).
Trial function:
$$x_{a} = A\cdot t + B$$ Substitute:

$$x_{a} = A\cdot t + B$$ } $$\frac{dx}{dt} + 3x = 2t + 1$$
$$\frac{dx_{a}}{dt} = A$$

$$A + 3(A \cdot t + B) = 2t + 1$$ Work out:
$$(3A)\cdot t + (A + 3B) = 2t + 1$$ This must be true for every value of t.
So: $3A = 2$, and $A + 3B = 1$
So $A = \frac{2}{3}$ and $\frac{2}{3} + 3B = 1 \rightarrow B = \frac{1}{9}$
So: $x_{a} = \frac{2}{3}t + \frac{1}{9}$
The general solutions is: $x = \frac{2}{3}t + \frac{1}{9} + C\cdot e^{-3t}$


#
Lesson 4 ⮜ ... ⮞ Lesson 6

/Differential-Equation-Laplace/Lesson-6.title: Lesson 6
/Differential-Equation-Laplace/Lesson-6.content:
# ➤ [Dashboard]() ➤ [Differential Equation & Laplace](Differential%20Equation%20&%20Laplace/Differential%20Equation%20&%20Laplace.md)

Linear higher-order differential equations

General form:
$$a_{n} \frac{d^{n}x}{dt^{x}} + a_{n-1} \frac{d^{n-1}x}{dt^{n-1}}+\cdots + a_{1}\frac{dx}{dt}+a_{0}x = r(t)$$ if $r(t) = 0$ then the differential equation is homogeneous.
We restrict ourselves to situations where all $a_{k}$ are constant.
This is then called: a homogeneous linear higher order differential equation with constant coefficients.


Approach

$$a_{n} \frac{d^{n}x}{dt^{x}} + a_{n-1} \frac{d^{n-1}x}{dt^{n-1}}+\cdots + a_{1}\frac{dx}{dt}+a_{0}x = r(t)$$ What type of function can be a solution of this?
Remember: an exponential function has a special property: the derivative is an exponential again.
So: in search for solution, look for exponentials.


Example

$$\frac{d^{2}x}{dt^{2}}+4\frac{dx}{dt}+3x=0$$ Trial function: $x = C\cdot e^{\lambda t}$
Substitute: $$x = C\cdot e^{\lambda t}$$ $$\frac{dx}{dt} = C\cdot e^{\lambda t}\cdot\lambda$$ $$\frac{d^{2}x}{dt^{2}} = C\cdot e^{\lambda t}\cdot\lambda^{2}$$ $$\Rightarrow C\cdot e^{\lambda t}\cdot\lambda^{2}+4\cdot C\cdot e^{\lambda t}\cdot\lambda+3\cdot C\cdot e^{\lambda t} = 0$$ $$C\cdot e^{\lambda t}\cdot(\lambda^{2} +4\lambda + 3) = 0$$ Of cause $C = 0$ gives a solution (the differetial equation is homogeneous).
The factor $e^{\lambda t}$ cannot be equal to 0.
The other solution are obtained by: $$\lambda^{2} + 4\lambda + 3 = 0$$ This is an ordinary quadratic equation.
$$(\lambda + 1)(\lambda + 3) = 0$$ $$\lambda = -1 \text{or} \lambda = -3$$ So the solutions have the form: $$x = Ce^{-t} \text{of} x = Ce^{-3t}$$ But also a combination of these two forms gives a solution. (substitute).
The general solution therefore has two constants: $$x = C_{1}e^{-t} + C_{2}e^{-3t}$$


General

$$a_{n} \frac{d^{n}x}{dt^{x}} + a_{n-1} \frac{d^{n-1}x}{dt^{n-1}}+\cdots + a_{1}\frac{dx}{dt}+a_{0}x = r(t)$$ From this differential equation we obtain an ordinaru equation.
$$a_{n}\lambda^{n} + a_{n-1}\lambda^{n-1}+\cdots+a_{1}\lambda+a_0=0$$ This is called the characteristic equation of the DE.
The solutionof the characteristic equation are the base for the solution of the DE.
Consider the solutions of the characteristic equation.
To an $n_{th}$ order differntial equation belongs a characteristic equation of $n_{th}$ degree.
This has n solutions.
We distinguish three solutions:
I. All different solutions (distinct)
II. Some solutions are the same (repeated)
III. Some solutions are complex (irreductible)


Situation I: distinct

Suppose the solutions of the characteristic equation are $\lambda_{1}, \lambda_{2}, \cdots, \lambda_{n}$, all different.
TThen the solution of the DE is: $$x = C_{1}e^{\lambda_{1}t}+C_{2}e^{\lambda_{2}t} + \cdots + C_{n}e^{\lambda_{n}t}$$


Situation II: repeated

Suppose the solutions of the characteristic equation are $\lambda_{1}, \lambda_{2}, \cdots, \lambda_{n}$ and some of them are equal.
For example $\lambda_{1} = \lambda_{2}$
Then the solution of the DE is:
$$x = C_{1}e^{\lambda_{1}t}+C_{2}\cdot t\cdot e^{\lambda_{2}t}+C_{3}e^{\lambda_{3}t}+\cdots+C_{n}e^{\lambda_{n}t}$$


Situation III: irreducible

Suppose the solutions of the characteristic equation are $\lambda_{1}, \lambda_{2}, \cdots, \lambda_{n}$ and some are complex.
These solutions always come in pairs (conjugate).
$$\lambda = a + bj \text{or} \lambda = a - bj$$ The corresponding solution of the DE is then:
$$x = C_{1}e^{at}\cdot\cos(bt)+C_{2}\cdot e^{at}\cdot\sin(bt)$$


#
Lesson 5 ⮜ ... ⮞ Lesson 7

/Differential-Equation-Laplace/Lesson-7.title: Lesson 7
/Differential-Equation-Laplace/Lesson-7.content:
# ➤ [Dashboard]() ➤ [Differential Equation & Laplace](Differential%20Equation%20&%20Laplace/Differential%20Equation%20&%20Laplace.md)

Boundary values

If we want to solve a specific second-order differential equation, two boundary values are necessary.
Often these boundary values are given like this:
$$\frac{d^{2}x}{dt^{2}} + 4 \frac{dx}{dt} + 3x = 0, x(0) = -1, Dx(0) = 5$$ The last part means: if $t = 0$ then $\frac{dx}{dt} = 5$


Solution

$$\frac{d^{2}x}{dt^{2}} + 4 \frac{dx}{dt} + 3x = 0, x(0) = -1, Dx(0) = 5$$ Characteristic equation: $\lambda^{2} + 4\lambda + 3 = 0$
$$(\lambda + 3)(\lambda + 1) = 0 \rightarrow \lambda = -3 \text{of} \lambda = -1$$ General solution DE: $x = C_{1}e^{-3t}+C_{2}e^{-t}$
$$x(0) = -1: -1 = C_{1}e^{0} + C_{2}e^{0} \rightarrow C_{1} + C_{2} = -1$$ Before we can substitute the second boundary value, we must differentiate the general solution:
$$\frac{dx}{dt} = C_{1}e^{-3t}\cdot(-3)+C_{2}e^{-t}\cdot(-1)=-3C_{1}e^{-3t}-C_{2}e^{-t}$$ $$Dx(0) = 5: 5 = -3C_{1}e^{0}-C_{2}e^{0} \rightarrow -3C_{1} - C_{2} = 5$$ $$x=C_{1}e^{-3t}+C_{2}e^{-t}$$
$$C_{1} + C_{2} = -1$$ $$-3C_{1} - C_{2} = 5$$ Two equations with two unknowns:
Sum: $-2C_{1} + 0C_{2} = 4 -> C_{1} = -2$
Substitute: $C_{2} = -1 - (-2) = 1$
Solution: $-2e^{-3t} + e^{-t}$
Check if the boundary values are value.


Not-homogenous

Just like the first order equation: first calculate the homogenous part of the solution: $x_{h}$
Then find a solution $x_{a}$ in the form of the righthandside and all of its derivatives.
The general solution is:
$$x = x_{a} + x_{h}$$

Example

$$\htmlClass{springgreen}{\frac{d^{2}x}{dt^{2}}} + 4\htmlClass{blue}{\frac{dx}{dt}} + 3\htmlClass{salmon}{x} = 6t$$ Characteristic equation: $$\lambda^{2} + 4\lambda + 3 = 0$$ $$x_{h} = C_{1}e^{-3t} + C_{2}e^{-t}$$ $$x_{a} = At + B$$ $$\frac{dx_{a}}{dt} = A$$ $$\frac{d_{2}x_{a}}{dt^{2}}$$ Substitute: $$\htmlClass{springgreen}{0} + 4\htmlClass{blue}{A} + 4(\htmlClass{salmon}{At + B}) = 6$$ $$3At + 4A + 3B = 6t$$ $$\htmlClass{salmon}{3At} + \htmlClass{blue}{4A + 3B} = \htmlClass{salmon}{6t} + \htmlClass{blue}{0}$$ $$\htmlClass{salmon}{3A = 6}$$ $$\htmlClass{blue}{4A + 3B = 0}$$ $$A = 2 \text{ and } B = -\frac{8}{3}$$ So: $x_{a} = 2t - \frac{8}{3}$
Solution: $x = 2t - \frac{8}{3} + C_{1}e^{-3t} + C_{2}e^{-t}$

# > [Dashboard]() > [Electrics Circuits AC](Electric%20Circuits%20AC/Electrics%20Circuits%20AC.md)

Capacitor

$$Z_{C} = \frac{1}{j\omega C}$$ $Z_{C}: $ impedance $[\Omega]$
$\omega: $ angular frequency $[\text{rad}\cdot\text{s}^{-1}]$
$C: $ capacitance $[\text{F}]$


Inductor

$$Z_{L} = j\omega L$$ $Z_{L}$: impedance $[\Omega]$
$\omega: $ angular frequency $[\text{rad}\cdot\text{s}^{-1}]$
$L: $inductance $[\text{H}]$


Impedance in serie

$$Z_{total} = Z_{1} + Z_{2}$$


Impedance in parallel

$$Z_{total} = \left[\frac{1}{Z_{1}} + \frac{1}{Z_{2}}\right]^{-1}$$


# Filters

Low Pass


 $$H_{s} = \frac{V_{out}}{V_{in}}=\frac{1}{j\omega RC + 1}$$

# Assignment 1 - AC power Forjanic Remy (511448), EEL1V.IB ## Question 1 $pf = 0.75$, $f = 50\text{Hz}$, $V_{rms} = 230\text{V}$
$S = \frac{511448}{100} = 5114.48\text{VA}$
Calculate $I_{rms}$
$I_{rms}=\frac{S}{U_{rms}}=\frac{5114.48}{230}\approx22.2\text{A}$
Calculate $P$ and $Q$ of the load
$\begin{align*}P &= U_{rms} \times I_{rms} \times cos(\varphi)\newline&=230\times22.2\times0.75\newline&\approx3829.5\text{W}\end{align*}$
$\begin{align*}S^{2}&=P^{2}+Q^{2}\newline\Rightarrow Q\space &= \sqrt{S^{2} - P^{2}}\newline&=\sqrt{5114.48^{2} - 3829.5^{2}}\newline&\approx3390.1\text{var}\end{align*}$
Calculate $R$ and $L$ value of the load
$R = \frac{U_{rms}}{I_{rms}}=\frac{230}{22.2}\approx10.36\ohm$
$\begin{align*}pf&=\frac{R}{|Z|}\newline\Rightarrow|Z|&=\frac{R}{pf}\newline&=\frac{10.36}{0.75}\approx13.81\ohm\end{align*}$
$\begin{align*}X_{L}&=\sqrt{|Z|^{2} - R^{2}}\newline&=\sqrt{13.81^{2} - 10.36^{2}}\newline&\approx9.13\ohm\end{align*}$
$\begin{align*}L &= \frac{X_{L}}{2\pi \times f}\newline&=\frac{9.13}{2\pi \times 50}\newline&\approx29.06\text{mH}\end{align*}$
## Question 2 plot the voltage across $RL$, the source current and its instantaneous power
![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment1.2.1.png) What is the frequency of the instantaneous power?
![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment1.2.2.png) What is the minimum and maximum instantaneous power?
![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment1.2.3.png) $f \approx 100\text{Hz}$ Also determine $I_{rms}$ using the simulation plots
![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment1.2.4.png) $I_{rms} = \frac{I_{peak}}{\sqrt{2}} = \frac{21.76}{\sqrt{2}} \approx 15.38\text{A}$ Verify by using the simulation plots, the power factor
![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment1.2.5.png) $\Delta t = 12.27\text{ms}$
$\varphi = 2\pi \times f \times \Delta t = 2\pi \times 50 \times 12.27\times10^{-3}\approx3.85\text{rad}$
$pf = \cos(\varphi) = \cos(3.85) \approx 0.76$ ## Question 3 Calculate $C$ when $pf = 0.9$ lagging
$pf = 0.9$
$\varphi = \cos^{-1}(0.9)=0.451\text{rad}$
$Q=U_{rms}*I_{rms}*sin(\varphi) = 2225$
$Q_{L} = \frac{U_{rms}^{2}}{X_{L}} = 5794\text{var}$
$Q_{C} = Q - Q_{L} = 2225 - 5794 = -3559\text{var}$
$X_{C} = \frac{U_{rms}^{2}}{Q_{C}}=14.86\ohm$
$C = \frac{1}{X_{C}*100\pi}=\frac{1}{14.86*100\pi}=214.2\mu F$
plot the voltage across $RL$, the source current and its instantaneous power
![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment1.3.1.png) What is the frequency of the instantaneous power?
![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment1.3.2.png) What is the minimum and maximum instantaneous power?
![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment1.3.3.png) $f \approx 100\text{Hz}$ Also determine $I_{rms}$ using the simulation plots
![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment1.3.4.png) $I_{rms} = \frac{I_{peak}}{\sqrt{2}} = \frac{18.77}{\sqrt{2}} \approx 13.27\text{A}$ Verify by using the simulation plots, the power factor
![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment1.3.5.png) $\Delta t = 8.77\text{ms}$
$\varphi = 2\pi \times f \times \Delta t = 2\pi \times 50 \times 8.77\times10^{-3}\approx2.77\text{rad}$
$pf = \cos(\varphi) = \cos(2.77) \approx 0.93$ ## Question 4 Calculate $C$ when $pf = 0.9$ leading
$$\varphi = -\cos^{-1}(0.9)=-0.451$$ $$Q=U_{rms}*I_{rms}*sin(\varphi) = -2225\text{var}$$ $$Q_{L} = \frac{U_{rms}^{2}}{X_{L}} = 5794\text{var}$$ $$Q_{C} = Q - Q_{L} = 2225 - 5794 = -8019\text{var}$$ $$X_{C} = -\frac{U_{rms}^{2}}{Q_{C}}=6.60\ohm$$ $$C = \frac{1}{X_{C}*100\pi}=482.5\mu F$$ plot the voltage across $RL$, the source current and its instantaneous power
![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment1.4.1.png) What is the frequency of the instantaneous power?
![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment1.4.2.png) What is the minimum and maximum instantaneous power?
![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment1.4.3.png) $f \approx 100\text{Hz}$ Also determine $I_{rms}$ using the simulation plots
![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment1.4.4.png) $I_{rms} = \frac{I_{peak}}{\sqrt{2}} = \frac{38.03}{\sqrt{2}} \approx 26.89\text{A}$ Verify by using the simulation plots, the power factor
![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment1.4.5.png) $\Delta t = 6.58\text{ms}$
$\varphi = 2\pi \times f \times \Delta t = 2\pi \times 50 \times 6.58\times10^{-3}\approx2.07\text{rad}$
$pf = \cos(\varphi) = \cos(2.07) \approx 0.48$

/Power-Circuits/Assignment-2.title: Assignment 2
/Power-Circuits/Assignment-2.content:
# Assignment 2 - Transformers Forjanic Remy (511448), EEL1V.IB $R_{1} = \frac{511448}{10000}=51.1448\ohm$ $f = 50\text{Hz}$ ## Question 1 ![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment2/circuit.png) Calculate the turns ratio of the transformer
$a = \frac{\sqrt{10}}{\sqrt{1000}} = 0.1$ Calculate the secondary voltage and current
$V_{2} = V_{1}\cdot{a} = {325}\cdot{0.1}=32.5V$
$I_{2} = \frac{V_{2}}{R_{1}}=\frac{32.5}{51.1448}=0.635A=635mA$
![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment2/2.1.png) Calculate the primary current
$I_{1} = {I_{2}}\cdot{a} = {0.635}\cdot{0.1} = 0.0635A = 63.5mA$
![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment2/2.2.png) What is the value of the resistance as seen by the source?
$R' = \frac{R_{1}}{a^{2}} = \frac{51.1448}{0.01}=5114.48\ohm$ Simulate the transformer and verify the calculation
$I_{2} = 634.4mA \approx 635mA$
$V_{2} = 32.4V \approx 32.5V$
$I_{1} = 62.3mA \approx 63.5mA$
## Question 2 ![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment2/citcuit2.png) Calculate the secondary voltage and current
$V_{2} = V_{1}\cdot{\frac{\sqrt{10}+\sqrt{10}}{\sqrt{1000}}} = {325}\cdot{0.2}=65V$
$I_{2} = \frac{V_{2}}{R_{1}}=\frac{65}{51.1448}=1.27A$
![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment2/3.1.png) Calculate the primary current
$I_{1} = {I_{2}}\cdot{a} = {1.27}\cdot{0.2} = 0.255A=255mA$
![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment2/3.2.png) Simulate the transformer and verify the calculation
$I_{2} = 1.27mA \approx 1.27A$
$V_{2} = 64.8V \approx 65V$
$I_{1} = 252.4mA \approx 255mA$
## Question 3 ![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment2/circuit3.png) Calculate the secondary voltage and current
$V_{2} = V_{1}\cdot{\frac{\sqrt{10}}{\sqrt{1000}}} = {325}\cdot{0.1}=32.5V$
Since the power of the input source stays the same, the current is also the same as in the 1st Question, therefore:
$I_{2} = 0.635mA$
![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment2/4.1.png) Calculate the primary current
$I_{1} = {I_{2}}\cdot{a} = {0.635}\cdot{0.1} = 0.0635A=63.5mA$
![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment2/4.2.png) Simulate the transformer and verify the calculation
$I_{2} = 634.6mA \approx 635mA$
$V_{2} = 32.5V \approx 32.5V$
$I_{1} = 62.4mA \approx 63.5mA$

/Power-Circuits/Assignment-3.title: Assignment 3
/Power-Circuits/Assignment-3.content:
# Assignment 3 - Rectifier Forjanic Rémy (511448) $C_{1} = \frac{511448}{1000} = 511.448\mu f$
$U_{max} = 24V$
$f = 50Hz$ ## Question 1 - Half wave rectifier ![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment3/1.circuit.png) Calculate the average voltage across the load and the voltage ripple.
$\begin{align*}U_{dc} &\approx \left(1 - \frac{1}{2fR_{L}C}\right)V_{max} \\&\approx \left(1 - \frac{1}{(2)(50)(100)(511.448\times10^{-6})}\right)(24)\approx19.31V\end{align*}$
![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment3/1.1.udc.png) $\begin{align*}F_{r} &= \frac{1}{fR_{L}C}\\&=\frac{1}{(50)(100)(511.448\times10^{-6})}=0.391=39.1\%\end{align*}$
$\begin{align*}V_{rpp}=F_{r}\cdot U_{dc}=(0.391)(19.31)=7.55V\end{align*}$
![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment3/1.1.ur.png) There is a difference of $\approx 1V$ between the simulation and the calculation, this could be due to the fact that during the calculation all the components are assumed perfect, which might not be the case during the simulation. Calculate the peak current though the capacitor and the diode.
If we assume that the diode create a voltage drop of $0.7V$:
$\begin{align*}I_{R_{L}}=\frac{U_{max}-0.7}{R_{L}}=\frac{23.3}{100}=0.233A=233mA\end{align*}$
![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment3/1.2.ir.png) $\begin{align*}I_{C}=\omega CU_{max}=(100\pi)(511.448\times10^{-6})(23.3)=3.74A\end{align*}$
![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment3/1.2.ic.png) $\begin{align*}I_{D} = I_{C} + I_{R_{L}}=3.74 + 0.233 = 3.974A\end{align*}$
![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment3/1.2.id.png) ## Question 2 - Half wave rectifier with series inductance With $L = 1mH$
![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment3/2.1.circuit.png) What is the influence of the inductor on the maximum voltage?
![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment3/2.1.1.png) When we add the inductor, the maximum voltage decreases.
What is the influence on the ripple voltage

# Assignment 4 - MOSFET Forjanic Rémy (511448) $R = 5.11448\Omega$ ## Question 1 - Switching a resistor ![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment4/4.1.a.circuit.png) What is the maximum voltage across the MOSFET?.
![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment4/4.1.a.1.png) What is the average current throught the resistor?.
![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment4/4.1.a.2.png) What is the maximum current through the resistor R1 (ON state)?.
![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment4/4.1.a.3.png) What is the voltage $V_{ds}$.
![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment4/4.1.a.4.png) Calculate the maximum power dissipation for D = 1 (continuously ON).
For $T_{a} = 25°C$
$P_{max} = (T_{max} - T_{a}) \div R_{th} = (150 - 25) \div 50 = 2.5W$
For $T_{a} = 70°C$
$P_{max} = (T_{max} - T_{a}) \div R_{th} = (150 - 70) \div 50 = 1.6W$
Calculate the junction temperature $T_{J}$ for $T_{ambient} = 25°C$, $D = 1$ $T_{j} = T_{a} + R\Theta ja \cdot P = 25 + 50 \cdot 2.5 = 150°C$ Calculate the junction temperature $T_{J}$ for $T_{ambient} = 25°C$, $D = 1$ $T_{j} = T_{a} + R\Theta ja \cdot P = 50 + 50 \cdot 1.6 = 150°C$ Calculate the junction temperature $T_{J}$ for $T_{ambient} = 25°C$, $D = 1$ Off State:
$W_{off} = 0$
Beacuse there is no current flowing throught the mosfet.

On State: $t_{on} = \frac{1}{2f} = \frac{1}{10000} = 0.1ms$
$W_{on} = U_{on} \times I_{on} \times t_{on} = 88m\times 4.7 \times 0.1m = 41.36\mu J$
Changing State:
Assuming $t_{c}(on) = t_{c}(off)$
$t_{c} = t_{rise} + t_{fall} = 8.5n + 17n = 25.5n$
$W_{c} = (U_{off} - U_{on})\times I_{on} \cdot t_{c} = (24 - 88m)\cdot 4.7 \cdot 25.5n = 2.866\mu J$

$W_{tot}= W_{on} + W_{off} + 2\cdot W_{c} = 41.36 + 2\cdot2.866 = 47.1\mu J$
$P_{avg} = \frac{W_{tot}}{T}=\frac{47.1\mu}{0.2m}=0.235W$
$T_{j} = T_{a} + R\Theta ja \cdot P = 25 + 50 \cdot 0.235 = 36.75°C$ ## Question 2 - Switching of RL without anti parallel diode ![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment4/4.2.circuit.png) What is the maximum voltage across the mosfet ![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment4/4.2.2.png) ## Question 3 - Switching of RL with anti parallel diode ![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment4/4.3.circuit.png) What is the maximum voltage across the mosfet ![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment4/4.3.1.png) What is the average current? ![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment4/4.3.2.png) What is the peak-peak ripple current? ![](Power%20Circuits/res/assignment4/4.3.3.png)

# > [Dashboard]() > [Power Circuits](Power%20Circuits/Power%20Circuits.md)

Electrical Power - DC

$$P = U\cdot I = R\cdot I^{2}=\frac{U^{2}}{R}$$ $P:$ power in $\text{W}$
$U:$ voltage in $\text{V}$
$I:$ current in $\text{I}$
$R:$ resistance in $\Omega$


AC voltage and current

 $$u(t) = U\sin(\omega t)$$ $$i(t) = I\cos(\omega t - \varphi)$$

Instantaneous power in AC circuits

 $$u(t) = U\sin(\omega t)$$ $$i(t) = I\cos(\omega t - \varphi)$$ $$p(t) = u(t)\cdot i(t)$$

$$p_{inst}(t)=UI\sin(\omega t)\sin(\omega t - \varphi)$$ $$p_{inst}(t)=UI\cos(\varphi)\sin^{2}(\omega t)-UI\sin(\varphi)\sin(\omega t)\cos(\omega t)$$


Average power

$$p_{inst}(t)=UI\cos(\varphi)\sin^{2}(\omega t)-UI\sin(\varphi)\sin(\omega t)\cos(\omega t)$$ Average power = integration of instantaneous power over one period.
$$\begin{align*}P_{average}&= \frac{1}{T}\int_{0}^{T}{P_{inst}}dt\newline&=\frac{UI}{T}\cos(\varphi)\int_{0}^{T}{\sin^{2}(\omega t)dt} \newline&= \frac{UI}{2\pi}\cos(\varphi)\int_{0}^{2\pi}{\sin^{2}(\omega t)d\omega t}\newline&=\frac{UI}{2\pi}\cos(\varphi)\int_{0}^{2\pi}\left(\frac{1-\cos(2\omega t)}{2}\right)d\omega t\newline&=\frac{UI}{2}\cos(\varphi)\end{align*}$$ $$U_{rms}=\sqrt{\frac{1}{T}\int_{0}^{T}{u^{2}(t)dt}}=\frac{U}{\sqrt{2}}$$ $$I_{rms}=\sqrt{\frac{1}{T}\int_{0}^{T}{i^{2}(t)dt}}=\frac{I}{\sqrt{2}}$$ $$\Rightarrow P_{average}= U_{rms}I_{rms}\cos(\varphi)$$


Real and reactive power

Real power: power consumed (dissipated) in the load = average power
$$P=U_{rms}I_{rms}\cos(\varphi)\text{ [W]}$$ Reactive power: power temporarily stored in $E$ or $H$ field and returned to the grid. $$Q=U_{rms}I_{rms}\sin{\varphi}\text{ [var]}$$


Reactive power

Inductor ($\varphi = 90\degree$, $\sin(\varphi) = 1$)
$$Q_{L}=U_{rms}I_{rms}=\frac{U^{2}_{rms}}{X_{L}}$$ Capacitor ($\varphi = -90\degree$, $\sin(\varphi) = -1$)
$$Q_{C}=-U_{rms}I_{rms}=-\frac{U^{2}_{rms}}{X_{C}}$$

# > [Dashboard]() > [Power Circuits](Power%20Circuits/Power%20Circuits.md)

Transformers

A transformer is an electrical device that transfer energy between two circuits through electromagnectic induction.


Applications

Step down the power line voltage.
DC power supplies.
Isolation between two parts of a circuit.
Impedance matching between sources and loads or sources and trasmission lines (e.g. data communication lines.
Physically insulate one circuit from another for safety.


Basic principle

[TODO: Image pg5]


Ideal transformer

Zero wining resistance.
The core permeability is infinite.
No leakage flux.
Core losses are assumed to be zero.
[TODO: Image pg6] $$E_{P} = N_{P}\frac{d\phi_{P}}{dt}$$ $$U_{P} = E_{P}$$ $$E_{S}=N_{S}\frac{d\phi_{S}}{dt}$$ $$U_{S} = E_{S}$$
Ideal:
$$\frac{d\phi_P}{dt}=\frac{d\phi_{S}}{dt}=\frac{d\phi}{dt}$$ $$\frac{U_{S}}{U_{P}}=\frac{E_{S}}{E_{P}}=\frac{N_{S} \frac{d\phi}{dt}}{N_{P} \frac{d\phi}{dt}} \Rightarrow \frac{U_{S}}{U_{P}}=\frac{N_{S}}{N_{P}}=n$$ Ideal: no power losses $\rightarrow I_{P}U_{P}=I_{S}U_{S}$
$$\frac{U_{S}}{U_{P}}=\frac{I_{P}}{I_{S}}=n$$
Step-up transformer: $N_{S} > N_{P}, U_{S} > U_{P}$
Step-down transformer: $N_{S} < N_{P}, U_{S} < U_{P}$

Winding

$$L=N \frac{\phi}{I}$$ } $$L=N\frac{\phi}{I}=N\frac{B\cdot A}{I}=N\frac{\mu\cdot N\cdot I}{l\cdot I}=N^{2}\frac{\mu\cdot A}{l}$$
$$\phi = B\cdot A$$
$$B=\mu\frac{N\cdot I}{l}$$

$\Rightarrow L$ is proportional to $N^{2}$

Real transformers

Core losses:
- Hysteresis losses - non linear
- Eddy currents - joule heating of the core.
Winding losses:
- Joule losses - resistance of the windings
- Leakage flux - not all flux passes from one winding to the other
